response.answer_text: Studies not confined by the arbitrary distinctions between disciplines. Skills, people, and knowledge from all areas and walks of life are synthesized in a team to solve a problem spanning everyone’s unique backgrounds, and investigate a big question to find new knowledge. It is the freeing of the intellect to develop its greatest potential. Take for instance the fields of systems engineering and astrobiology. Systems engineering is the study of how a system is designed, developed, tested, and implemented to serve a purpose for people. A system is a designed arrangement of components, such that the whole has capabilities beyond its components. Making the best systems in the best way requires knowledge of the mechanics of the system itself, as well as knowledge of the environment in which the system will function, knowledge relating to its purpose (from my experience, usually space science), knowledge of budget management, project management, outreach, administrative stuff, and team psychology. All of this knowledge is traditionally kept far away from each other in various scattered academic and professional silos called “disciplines”. But it must come together to put a rover on Mars. Similarly, astrobiology integrates fields like planetary geology, stellar astrophysics, climatology, microbiology, and biochemistry to study the habitability of various envirionments beyond present-day Earth. This includes other planetary bodies in the Solar System (many Mars missions have had astrobiology components or objectives), exoplanets, the universe itself, and past/future Earth. I’ve mostly cited Mars-related examples, but the possibilities are endless. Let your imagination run wild. Break free of the compartmentalization. You will have a more valuable skillset and experiences as a result—but the real motivation is the sheer intellectual satisfaction.
